comments.commentBody:
Roast at 400 for 30 min then dropped temp to 350 for an additional hour (flipped the duck every 30 minutes) added the Orange ginger sauce for an additional 15 min cook time..total cook time 1hr45 min
The duck came out perfect. Will definitely be using this recipe again!
The sauce took a very very long time to reduce but when it did it was delicious also

Loved this, very easy and flavorful. I used about 1/4 t cayenne but it could easily have used more. My mistake was to buy pre-cubed tofu (accidental); next time I'll cut larger cubes from a block for better texture/less surface area competition with the rice (if that's the way to put it).
Martin, the only thing elegant is your attempt to defend. The cluing is the key. The puzzle is annoying, like someone who always corrects someone else.
Where do you see white beans?
And, too bad that every thing you suggest is what the Republican Party fights tooth and nail, to the detriment of their voters...who are oblivious.

michjas, there's an old song that goes:
"You can't always get what you want, but you get what you need."
Patrick k was definitely referring only to "need".
So since we've been spending a billion a day, printing money with no backing for the last 7 years,  you think it's time to print more?!

The dollar, as it continues to become too strong relative to foreign markets, should be devalued through opening the fed window, this time for the people. Options include 1. Rebuilding our infrastructure 2. Paying outstanding balances on the millennial student debt crisis, thereby stimulating spending 3. Investing in our decaying social sector, specifically mental health and education 4. Job training programs aimed at individuals being released from prison.  Too bad this is a sham democracy. Hope our oligarchs are feeling benevolent.
His record on "certain social issues" speaks for itself. Women are lesser. God is great. My way or the highway. Millennials, dismiss this poser and move on...next!

I hope Mr. Sutton feels like he has just been spoken to by a used car salesman. Kasich spoke to absolutely nothing in his question. He didn't say anything about the first part -- younger voters being more supportive of universal health care, gay marriage, or universal background checks. Not a word. And then he simply repeated your observations -- we need balanced budgets. Kasich was patronizing and cowardly. And left me thinking he doesn't have a clue what to do.

How, Mr. Kasich, are we going to "balance budgets, lower taxes," and "plug together to fix our schools?" You aren't exactly showing us how its done there in Ohio. And spare us the hand on the shoulder and the mussing of our hair while you wink at us and declare, "I love idealistic young people! Keep trying and never give up." What a load.
Yes, it could always be worse.  Look at the Detroit Lions.

Look it was time for Coughlin to move on. Perhaps work on his golf or tennis swing and gain some balance at this stage in his life. Sleeping in his office or working 18 hour days in such a competitive cutthroat environment is a younger mans game. TC should travel, enjoy his life bit away from football and in a couple of years go the Bill Polian consultative route for some moribund franchise.
How does their dismissal of Coughlin show that they are a class act? I think its just the opposite.

Nonsense. The best owners hire people who know how to do their jobs, and let those people do them. The worst owners tend to meddle, and make a mess of things.

When a team's a complete mess, the dysfunction almost always starts at the top.
The best thing about being a Packers fan is not having to deal with a bad owner.
They cheat?

The draft choices have been a disaster.  25 people on IR raises a lot of questions. But why do the Patriots have close to 12 wins a year forever while the Giants have losing seasons. And why let Tuck, Canty and the like go when you have no equal replacements. All that money over the cap and is is not being used. So many questions. Disturbing to say the least.

I'd remind Mr. Mara and Mr. Tisch that today there are many more effective ways of protesting continued mismanagement than flying a plane over the stadium towing a sign saying "15 years of lousy football ... we've had enough." The clock is already ticking, gentlemen and it ticks faster in this century.

"In N.F.L., Losing Never Seems to Be the Owners’ Fault"?

In contrast to baseball?
The Mets? Wilpon. (for years before this past one) Yankees? Steinbrunners.

NBA?
Dolan.

And for that matter when are the fatcat CEOs and corporate wunderkinds EVER "responsible" for manifest failure? Not in the land of golden handshakes and golden parachutes, that's for sure! Carly Fiorina, Richard Fuld, Angelo Mozillo, Hank Greenberg, etc, etc, etc...
If Griffey's 99.3% is a record, betting that Ruth did not get 100% would be a pretty safe bet.

Any of the voting sports writers who did not vote for Mays, Williams, Mantle, Joe Dimaggio, Koufax, and Seaver during their first year of eligibility should be required to explain to the public their reasons for not voting for these obvious and deserving Hall of Famers.

koufax was the best pitcher i saw in my lifetime. however, some thought he didn't have enough wins to make it in. mantle was my favourite baseball player, ever. some believe you need 3000 hits to make it into the hall. williams missed several years because of ww2 and korea so an exception could've been made for him......

Believe it or not but Griffey wasn't the only one who didn't get a unanimous vote. How about,willie Mays, ted williams, mickey mantle, joe dimaggio, sandy koufax, need i go on? Believe it or not I don't think Babe ruth did either!
Baggie 2017! (I'm from Houston and, therefore, biased and prejudiced.)
Probably Dick Young. From the grave.
Joe D and Yogi weren't elected on the first ballot? How can that have been possible?

In his last MLB season Puazza returned with the Oakland A's to play the Mets.  He hit a home run in his first at-bat.  The Shea Stadium crowd rose and gave him a standing ovation as he rounded the bases, concluding with a curtain call and tip of his cap.  I'm quite sure it was the only time an opposing player received a standing O in Queens.  That's how much the fans loved him.  Congrats Mike!

there was a player named henry aaron who was left off by nine voters. another named willie mays had, I think, 20 not name him. cobb and ruth were fair ballplayers too and who the hell didn't vote for them?
Piazza was a Met. If you're still confused, ask Piazza himself.
@ PointertoVoid: The day they let any of those guys in is the day they should close the doors and shut the place down.
Bonds, McGwire and Clemens brought the dark shadows of disgrace and greed to the game. Keep them out, forever, or disgrace the real athletes who do belong in the Hall.

Thank you for sharing these wonderful memories. I grew up in Queens and, before leaving NY must have gone by Shea thousands of times on the Flushing IRT and the highway. Your descriptions are very evocative of another time.

Lucky dog--
Nice memories and remarks. I'm also an original Met fan, and Irish (mother born in Ireland) and am happy to finally see a second Met cap in the HOF.

After going without a NL team for 4 years after the Dodgers left, we older fans were relieved. excited, and deeply in love with the new team. And love is always blind. Let's go Mets!

My late father was an original Mets fan, he arrived from Ireland in 1957 and despite the rampant discrimination against the Irish, he worked incredibly hard and loved the NY Mets from day 1. His life was work every day and the Mets on the radio and then on TV whenever possible. When they won the Series in 1969, he came home with turf from Shea, we never forgot how happy he was. He died in 1996, and we kept going to Shea to carry on his legacy as a fan. So we were honored to be there to see Mike Piazza play, and the thrill of that will stay with us for our lifetimes.  We will never forget the first game at Shea after 9/11, when we needed hope, Mike was there. We miss so many good things - we miss Dad, we miss Shea, we miss watching Mike play - and we are so happy to see a true gentleman and great player get into the Hall today. Thank you, Mr. Piazza - and many congratulations on this well deserved honor. Know that you make all Mets fans, the ones here and the ones in the Shea in the Sky, very happy today and always. When you go to Cooperstown, we'll follow you there to see your plaque - you will be the reason we go there. That's how much you mean to us.

I disagree. Bonds, Clemens, McGuire, and eventually A-roid, among others, were obvious cheaters, and their cheating distorted long-time baseball records in disastrous fashion. Taking steroids is not remotely comparable to the "uppers" the players took back in the day to stay awake after long bus and train rides.

If Bonds, Clemens, or any of the others are ever elected to the HOF, they should take the sign down and close the doors forever. The last thing baseball needs after this long, sordid era is a Hall of Shame populated with steroid cheats.
